questions.text: True statement regarding hypothermia during anaesthesia is

choices.text: Occur irrespective of the type of anesthesia
Conduction is the primary means by which body loses heat
It is always beneficial to the patient

questions.solution:
True statement regarding hypothermia during anaesthesia is it occurs irrespective of the type of the type of anesthesia.

During GA shivering is abolished by suppression of hypothalamus.

  • Hypothermia is protective during cerebral or cardiac ischemia and it is used in neurosurgery, cardiac surgery, carotid artery surgery / prolonged surgeries, where tissue ischemia is anticipated, in recovery after cardiac arrest and for neonatal asphyxia.
  • As hypothermia is arrythmogenic it is C/I in arrhythmia.
  • Hypothermia during anesthesia occur in nearly every patient during both general and regional (spinal/epidural) anesthesia, unless steps are taken to prevent this complication.
  • Body loses heat mainly by internal re-distribution and radiation.
  • It is beneficial (in ischemia) as well as deleterious (coagulopathy, cardiac arrhythmia, wound infection etc.) to patients.
  • It can be prevented by giving warm fluids only if large amounts of IV fluids are to be administered. However, patients cannot be warmed by using heated fluids because the fluid cannot (much) exceed body temperature.

questions.text: Stage of surgical anesthesia during ether administration is

choices.text: Regular respiration to cessation of breathing
Loss of consciousness to beginning of regular respiration

questions.solution:
Stages of Anesthesia:

  • Stage I (stage of analgesia or disorientation): from beginning of induction of general anesthesia to loss of consciousness.
  • Stage II (stage of excitement or delirium): from loss of consciousness to onset of automatic breathing.
  • Stage III (stage of surgical anesthesia): from onset of automatic respiration to respiratory paralysis.
  • Stage IV: from stoppage of respiration till death.

questions.text: Supra MAC anaesthetic concentration changes EEG waves from:
questions.solution:
EEG changes during induction:

  • The EEG patterns of different anesthetic agents are similar when the concentrations are at sub-MAC level.
  • At the beginning, lower doses of anesthetic essentially increase the amplitude of the beta band in the frontal regions and decrease the amplitude of the alpha band.
  • When the anesthetic concentration is increased to the surgical level, the frequency of theta and delta bands decrease, whereas their amplitudes increase.
  • Further increases in the anesthetic concentration generate a special EEG pattern known as burst suppression (BS).

questions.text: During laryngoscopy and endotracheal intubation which of the following maneuver is not performed:

choices.text: Extension of the head at atlanto-occipital joint
During laryngoscopy with miller’s blade, the epiglottis is lifted up by the tip
The laryngoscope is lifted upward levering over the upper incisor

questions.solution:
The laryngoscope is lifted upward levering over the upper incisor.

  • Direct laryngoscopy is performed in sniffing position - head elevation 5-10 cm above the surgical table, flexion of the cervical spine and extension at the atlantooccipital joint.
  • During laryngoscopy with miller’s blade, the epiglottis is lifted up by the tip.
  • While performing laryngoscopy, the scope is lifted upwards and never levered over the upper incisors.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was brought to the casualty with complaints of palpitations and dizziness. His pulse rate was 130/min and blood pressure 120/70 mm Hg. His ECG is shown below. What is the line of management?
questions.solution:
The patient has monomorphic ventricular tachycardia but it hasn’t caused hemodynamic deterioration.  So pharmacological treatment is initiated with procainamide.

Procainamide is a class Ia antiarrhythmic drug. The loading dose for procainamide is 20 to 50 mg/min which is given until the arrhythmia is suppressed, hypotension develops, the QRS prolongs by 50% or a total dose of 17 mg/kg is administered. The maintenance dose is 1 to 4 mg/min.

If the patient is unstable with any one of the following:

  • Pulseless
  • Hypotension
  • Acutely altered mental status
  • Signs of shock
  • Ischemic chest discomfort
  • Acute heart failure

   Then immediate synchronized cardioversion should be given

   Monophasic – 360 J

   Biphasic - 120 J

It is essential to rule out the reversible causes of ventricular tachycardia like Hypoxemia, hypercapnia, hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia (or both), digitalis toxicity and acid-base disturbances.

questions.text: An 8-year old child is brought to the casualty in respiratory distress. In order to intubate this child, which is the appropriate size of endotracheal tube to be used?
questions.solution:
The appropriate size of the endotracheal tube for a child is chosen by the formula: 4 + age/4.

 

So the correct sized tube for this child would be 6 mm.

  • Size of an endotracheal tube usually refers to the internal diameter in mm. Rarely  the French scale is used where the size corresponds to the external diameter multiplied by 3.
  • For adults, usually a 7-mm is used for women and an 8-mm ETT is used for men.
               Age   Internal Diameter (mm)        Length (cm)
Full-term infant 3.5 12
Child 4  + Age/4 14 + Age/2
Adult Female 7.0–7.5 21 (average)
Male 7.5–9.0 23 (average)
  • Besides age, choice of an endotracheal tube also depends on the presence of airway pathologies and the reason behind placement of the tube.
  • Smaller sized tubes lead to increase airway resistance and increased work of breathing.
  • Larger tubes have higher risk of laryngeal and tracheal trauma and sore throat.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was brought to the casualty with multiple stab injuries over the abdomen. He was immediately prepared for emergency surgery and an endotracheal tube was inserted. Following intubation,  capnography was performed and end-tidal CO2 was detected. But his oxygen saturation dropped to 60 and there were no breath sounds audible over the left hemithorax. This is probably because of?
questions.solution:
• Detection of end-tidal CO2 but dropping oxygen saturation and hypoxia with absent breath sounds over the left hemithorax point to endobronchial intubation into the right main bronchus.
  • Endobronchial intubation is first indicated by a sudden rise in peak inspiratory pressure.
  • Capnography and detection of end-tidal CO2 is the surest confirmation for endotracheal intubation but it does not differentiate endotracheal from endobronchial intubation.
  • Signs of endobronchial intubation.
  • Elevated peak inspiratory pressure and other airway pressures
  • Asymmetric chest expansion
  • Unilateral breath sounds
  • Hypoxemia
  • Signs of correct endotracheal intubation:
    • Detection of end tidal CO2 by capnography (SUREST CONFIRMATION)
    • Symmetric chest rise
    • Bilateral breath sounds
    • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
    • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
    • Large exhaled tidal volumes
    • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation
  • During an esophageal intubation, initial end tidal CO2 may be detected due to swallowed air but later becomes zero and there would be absence of breath sounds bilaterally with presence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

questions.text: Nitrous oxide was first introduced by
questions.solution:
Joseph Priestley produced nitrous oxide in 1772, and Humphry Davy fi rst noted its analgesic properties in 1800. Gardner Colton and Horace Wells are credited with having fi rst used nitrous oxide as an anesthetic for dental extractions in humans in 1844. Nitrous oxide’s lack of potency (an 80% nitrous oxide concentration results in analgesia but not surgical anesthesia) led to clinical demonstrations that were less convincing than those with ether.

  • August bier – performed the first spinal anesthesia in humans
  • Edmund Boyle – discovered the anesthetic machine
  • Oliver Wendell – coined the term anesthesia

History of Anaesthesia, Time line:

  • 1773 - Joseph Priestly first introduced Nitrous oxide
  • 1800 - Humphrey Davy published nitrous oxide
  • 1844 - Horace Wells administered nitrous oxide for dental analgesia
  • 16th October 1846 - William Morton public demonstration of diethyl ether at the Massachusetts general hospital. It is celebrated as world anaesthesia day
  • 1846- Oliver Wendell - coined the term anesthesia
  • 1847 - James Young Simpson administered chloroform for general anesthesia in England.
  • 1853 - John Snow administered chloroform to Queen Victoria for the birth of Prince Leopold.
  • 1857 - Claude Bernard discovered the effects of curare located at the myoneural junction.
  • 1884 - Carl Koller introduced the use of cocaine for ophthalmic surgery
  • 1889 - August Bier performed the first surgical spinal anesthesia
  • 1917- Edmund Boyle - discovered the anesthetic machine
  • 1926- John Lundy - coined the term balanced anesthesia

questions.text: Which is the most common anaphylactic agent during anesthesia?
questions.solution:
The most common anaphylactic agent during anesthesia is antibiotics.

This is followed by neuromuscular blocking agents.

Penicillins and cephalosporins are the most common causes of anaphylaxis among antibiotics.

questions.text: Irradiation of granulocytes before transfusion has the following advantages except?

choices.text: Reduced incidence of graft versus host disease

questions.solution:
• Irradiation of granulocytes adversely affects granulocyte function and doesn’t improve it.
  • Irradiation of granulocytes or use of leuko reduced blood components has several advantages over the use of packed red blood cells:
  • Decreased risk of graft versus host disease-which is due to engraftment of donor lymphocytes from the transfused blood products leading to an immune reaction against recipient tissues.
  • Reduces chances of febrile reactions.
  • Decreases pulmonary endothelial damage.
  • Decreases transmission of cytomegalovirus.
  • But the risk of bacterial contamination of platelets, transfusion related acute lung injury TRALI, and acute hemolytic reactions have not decreased with leukoreduction.

questions.text: Colloid used to decrease blood viscosity is?
questions.solution:
• Colloid used to decrease blood viscosity is dextran 40.
  • DEXTRAN is a highly branched polysaccharide produced by the bacterium Leuconostoc mesenteroides.
  • Dextran 40 has a molecular weight of 40,000 daltons.
  • It can reduce blood viscosity and cellular aggregation and improve microcirculation during low-flow states and hence it may be used in microvascular surgery.
  • It is given prophylactically to reduce the incidence of post-operative thromboembolism.

questions.text: Dead space is increased in all except:
questions.solution:
Dead space is increased in all except artificial airway. Dead space is the volume of a breath that does not participate in gas exchange. It is ventilation without perfusion.

  • Total dead space (Physiological dead space) = Anatomical dead space+ alveolar dead space.
  • Anatomical dead space is the area in the tracheobronchial tree where the gaseous exchange between the lung and capillaries doesn’t take place. It includes nasal cavity, larynx, trachea, bronchi, end of the terminal bronchiole.
  • Alveolar dead space is the volume of gas within unperfused alveoli (and thus not participating in gas exchange either)

 

 

Factors affecting dead space:

  • Posture:

         Upright - Increase

         Supine - Decrease

  • Position of Airway:

         Neck Extension - Increase

         Neck Flexion - Decrease

  • Others:

        Age - Increase

        Artificial airway - Decrease

        Positive pressure ventilation - Increase

        Drug anti-cholinergic - Increase

  • Pulmonary perfusion:

        Pulmonary embolism - Increase

        Hypotension - Increase

  • Pulmonary vascular disease:

        Emphysema - Increase

questions.text: A patient is undergoing pulmonary artery catheterization. While introducing Swan-Ganz catheter, its placement in the pulmonary artery is characterized by which of the following pressure tracing?
questions.solution:
Placement of the Swan-Ganz catheter in the pulmonary artery is characterized by a sudden increase in diastolic pressure and a change in waveform morphology. Diastolic pressure initially is higher than that in the right ventricle(RV).

Pulmonary artery catheterization is used to assess hemodynamic variables in sick patients undergoing major surgery. It is used to measure

  • Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP). In the presence of mitral valve pathology or a previous transplant, trans-septal left atrial catheterization is done.
  • Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (LVEDP)
  • Ventricular volume.
  • Cardiac output
  • Stroke volume
  • Confirm diagnosis of pulmonary artery hypertension
  • Assess severity of mitral stenosis

Absolute contraindications of pulmonary artery catheterization are right-sided endocarditis, tumors of the right heart, and lack of consent. Relative contraindications are left bundle branch block and pulmonary and tricuspid valve disorders.

Technique for pulmonary artery catheterization - Central venous access via the right internal jugular vein is most commonly used and is achieved by using Seldinger's technique. The Swan-Ganz catheter is inserted and waveforms start to appear once the catheter is in the right atrium. Respiratory variations of the waveform confirm intrathoracic placement. Once the catheter is in the right ventricle, transient ectopy due to irritation of the right ventricle by the balloon and catheter tip is common and rarely requires treatment. Continuous ECG monitoring is required.

The normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is between 4 to 12 mmHg. Elevated levels of PCWP might indicate severe left ventricular failure or severe mitral stenosis. The waveforms that can be observed are tabulated below:

Location Pressure tracing
Catheter passes via SVC to the right atrium  (Right atrial pressure) Low-pressure waves in systole and diastole. <5 mm Hg
The catheter enters the right ventricle  through the tricuspid valve (Right ventricle pressure) A sudden increase in systolic pressure with the same diastolic pressure 25 mm Hg systolic and 0-5 mm Hg diastolic
Enter the pulmonary artery through the pulmonary valve (Pulmonary artery pressure)

A sudden increase in diastolic pressure (about 10 mm Hg). Systolic pressure remains the same  

Dicrotic notch caused by the closure of the pulmonary valve

 25mmHg systolic and 10-20 mm Hg diastolic pressure
The catheter advances into a branch of the pulmonary artery where it wedges. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.  This reflects left atrial pressure Dampened pressure waveform 4-12 mm Hg

 

Complications of pulmonary artery catheterization:

  • Arrhythmias like ventricular fibrillation
  • Right bundle branch block
  • Complete heart block (if preexisting left bundle branch block)
  • Pulmonary artery rupture
  • Pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm
  • Catheter knots.

Other Options:

Option A: Sudden decrease in diastolic pressure is not the hallmark of entry into the pulmonary artery. After the initial increase in diastolic pressure in the pulmonary artery, during ventricular diastole, the RV diastolic pressure increases and the pulmonary artery diastolic pressure decreases due to the runoff of blood into the lungs. 

Options C and D: The systolic pressures of the pulmonary artery remain the same as those of the right ventricle in normal physiological conditions.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started as there was no pulse and the following rhythm was noted on the monitor. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario patient has an organized, apparently normal ECG without a palpable pulse, that is, the patient has pulseless electrical activity (PEA). Among the given options, the next step is to give 1 mg of epinephrine.

The immediate treatment for pulseless electrical activity is to give chest compressions and 1 mg epinephrine at the earliest. Following that, definitive treatment for the cause of PEA should be initiated.

It is essential to rule out the reversible causes of cardiac arrest. They include:

5 H’s:

  • Hypovolemia
  • Hypoxia
  • Hydrogen ion (acidosis)
  • Hypokalemia or hyperkalemia
  • Hypothermia

5 T’s:

  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Tamponade (cardiac)
  • Toxins
  • Thrombosis (pulmonary)
  • Thrombosis (coronary)

Other options : 

Option A: Defibrillation is done for treating shockable rhythms. An electric current is passed for a short interval to bring back sinus rhythm. 

Option B: Amiodarone 300 mg IV bolus is used in the treatment of shockable rhythms. After defibrillation CPR is continued for 2 min and then Epinephrine/ Amiodarone is administered alternatively and CPR is continued till sinus rhythm is established. 

Option D: 0.5 mg atropine is the first-line drug for acute symptomatic bradycardia.

questions.text: The maximum oxygen delivered by a nasal cannula is?
questions.solution:
The maximum oxygen delivered by a nasal cannula is 40%.

The nasal cannula is a low flow variable performance oxygen delivery system that can provide a maximum inspired oxygen concentration of 40% at flow rates greater than 10 L/ min for short periods. It is usually limited to a flow of 5-6 L/min to reduce the discomfort resulting from inadequate humidification and high flow into the nasal cavity. It may also cause drying and crusting of the nasal mucosa.

Oxygen delivery devices can be broadly divided into low flow oxygen devices (eg: nasal cannula, simple face mask, non-rebreathing mask) and high flow oxygen devices (eg: venturi mask).

questions.solution:

Ethyl violet is the most commonly used indicator, hence the answer is purple.

questions.text: True statement concerning compound A is _____

choices.text: Seen predominantly with high flow techniques

questions.solution:
• True statement concerning compound A is less common with Amsorb adsorbent.
  • Compound A is fluoromethyl-2,2-difluoro-1-(trifluoromethyl) vinyl ether which is the degradation product of sevoflurane by the strong bases like sodium hydroxide and potassium hydroxide present in calcium hydroxide–based carbon dioxide absorbents (soda lime)
  • Compound A is nephrotoxic, not neurotoxic. It is also associated with transient albuminuria and glucosuria

Factors that increase the concentration of compound A include:

  • Prolonged exposure to sevoflurane
  • Higher concentrations of sevoflurane in the anesthetic circuit
  • Low flow anesthetic technique
  • The type of absorbent - baralyme and classic soda-lime had been with withdrawn due to a greater risk of compound A formation as they contain sodium hydroxide and potassium hydroxide. Potassium hydroxide produces a greater amount of compound A than sodium hydroxide. Newer soda-lime contains no potassium hydroxide.
    • Compound A formation is less or absent with amsorb due to its greater inertness.
  • Higher absorbent temperatures
  • Fresh absorbent
  • Desflurane on degradation with dry desiccated baralyme produces carbon monoxide. Although this phenomenon is seen with all halogenated inhalational anesthetics, it is maximum with desflurane ( desflurane ≥ enflurane > isoflurane >> halothane = sevoflurane)

questions.text: Normal hospital pipeline supply of air is?
questions.solution:
• Normal hospital pipeline supply pressure of all gases is at 50-55 psig
  • But the Maximum pressure in the E-cylinders:
    • 750 psig for nitrous oxide
    • 2000 psig for air
    • 2000 psig for oxygen
  • Since these pressures are much higher than the hospital pipeline supply pressure, each cylinder is passéd through a high pressure regulator, which reduces the high pressures inside the cylinder to a lower, nearly constant pressure of 45 psig which is suitable for use in the anesthesia machine.

Pressure sections of Anaesthesia work stations:

questions.text: True regarding succinyl choline are all except

choices.text: Produces both phase I and phase II block
The rise in intracranial  pressure can be blocked by vecuronium

questions.solution:
• Succinyl choline is a depolarizing muscle relaxant
  • It produces both phase I and phase II( which resembles non-depolarizing neuromuscular block)
  • Succinylcholine can produce a rise in intracranial pressure as a result of cerebral activation and increased cerebral blood flow. This is because muscle fasciculations produced by succinyl choline leads to activation of muscle spindle which subsequently increase cerebral activity.
  • This increase in ICP is blocked by paralysis with a non-depolarising muscle relaxant   like vecuronium and administering intravenous lidocaine (1.5–2.0 mg/kg) 2–3 min prior to intubation.

questions.text: DIBUCAINE NUMBER is used to assess:

choices.text: Genetic make up of an individual with respect to butyryl cholinesterase

questions.solution:
Dibucaine number indicates the genetic makeup of an individual with respect to butyrylcholinesterase, BUT it does not measure the concentration of the enzyme in the plasma substrate.

Dibucaine is a local anesthetic which measures pseudocholinesterase function but not the amount of enzyme.

It inhibits normal pseudocholinesterase activity by 80% but inhibits atypical enzyme activity by only 20%.

Dibucaine number refers to the percentage of inhibition of pseudocholinesterase activity.

A patient with normal pseudocholinesterase has a dibucaine number of 80; a homozygote will have a dibucaine number of 20.

Therefore, adequacy of pseudocholinesterase can be determined

  • quantitatively in units per liter (a minor factor) - in laboratory
  • qualitatively-by dibucaine number (the major factor)

Dibucaine number:

  • High dibucaine number (80) means high quantity of normal and low quantity of atypical
  • Pseudocholinesterase : normal response to succinyl choline and mivacurium.
  • Low dibucaine number (<30) means low quantity of normal and high quantity of atypical
  • Pseudocholinesterase : prolonged succinyl choline and mivacurium block.

questions.text: A 70 kg athlete was posted for surgery and he was administered succinylcholine due to unavailability of vecuronium. It was administered in intermittent dosing (total 640 mg). During recovery, the patient was not able to respire spontaneously & move limbs. What is the reason for the same?

choices.text: Muscular weakness due to fasciculation produced by succinylcholine
Undiagnosed muscular dystrophy and muscular weakness
Phase II blockade produced by succinyl choline
Pseudocholinesterase deficiency increasing action of succinylcholine

questions.solution:
The best answer to the above case scenario is phase II blockade produced by succinylcholine.

Phase II block is clinically seen with the dose >5 mg/kg.

Mechanism of action of succinylcholine:

  • Phase I block: continuous endplate depolarization and subsequent muscle relaxation.
  • Phase II block: seen with a large single dose, repeated doses, or a continuous infusion which can lead to desensitization of the receptors resulting in a prolonged neuromuscular blockade.

Causes of prolonged apnea include:

  • Atypical/pseudocholinesterase deficiency - can result in apnea even with a normal dose of succinylcholine
  • The altered response of endplate to depolarizing relaxant (myasthenia gravis)
  • Accumulation of succinylcholine leading to phase II blockade

Although options B, C, and D can lead to prolonged apnea, in the above case scenario, the patient has received ~9mg/kg of succinylcholine. Hence the most probable diagnosis is phase II blockade leading to prolonged apnea.

Related Pearl: Side effects of succinyl choline

The following are the side effects of succinyl choline:

  • Cardiovascular effects:
    • Sinus bradycardia
    • Junctional rhythms
    • Ventricular dysrhythmias
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Myalgia
  • Masseter spasm: Succinyl choline can trigger malignant hyperthermia
  • Increased intracranial pressure: Succinylcholine may lead to an activation of the EEG and slight increases in CBF and ICP in some patients.
  • Increased intraocular pressure
  • Increased intragastric pressure

questions.text: Mivacurium when given in high doses, all are true except

choices.text: Increase in dose increases the rapidity of onset

questions.solution:
Mivacurium when given in high doses, all are true except hypertension.Mivacurium is BENZYLISOQUINOLINE derivative non- depolarizing muscle relaxant.

  • It is the Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant due to its metabolism by pseudocholinesterase(butyrlycholinesterase). It has an onset of action within 2-3 minutes and a duration of action of 10-20 minutes.
  • Patients with atypical pseudocholinesterase will have prolonged duration of block of several hours following mivacuirum administration.
  • Can cause histamine release but in lesser quantities as compared to tubocurarine. It is seen only when the intravenous injection is given rapidly. Histamine release leads to hypotension, tachycardia and flushing.

Non-depolarizing Muscle relaxants are classified based on their duration of action into:

Ultra short acting (<10 minutes)

  • Gantacurium

Short-acting (10-20 minutes)

  • Mivacurium

 Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)

  • Atracurium
  • Cisatracurium
  • Vecuronium
  • Rocuronium

 Long-acting (>50 minutes)

  • Pancuronium
  • Pipecuronium
  • Doxacurium
  • Metocurine
  • d-tubocurarine

questions.text: During a laser vocal cord surgery there is a fire break out. What is not to be done?
questions.solution:
If there is a fire break out during laser vocal cord surgery, oxygen should be turned off, ventilation should be stopped, endotracheal tube removed and submerged in water and patient should be ventilated with facemask. At a later stage bronchoscopy done to assess airway damage, bronchial lavage. Steroids can be used for treatment.

Precautions to take during laser ENT surgery includes:

  • Nitrous oxide supports combustion and so is avoided during laser surgeries.
  • Endotracheal tube cuffs should be inflated with saline instead of air.
  • To avoid endotracheal tube ignition, saline soaked pledgets are kept in the airway.
  • Increased concentration of oxygen can cause fire, and so inspired oxygen concentration is kept very low.
  • A source of water is to be available in case a fire breaks out.
  • In case of a fire, all sources of oxygen and nitrogen should be cut off immediately and the fire extinguished with saline.

questions.text: Traction on which of the following elicits the oculocardiac reflex:
questions.solution:
Traction on  medial rectus elicits the oculocardiac reflex.

Oculocardiac Reflex:

  • It is a trigemino vagal reflex.
  • Results from traction on the medial rectus muscle, orbital periosteum, etc. It could also result from trauma to the eye, administering a retrobulbar block or by even compression of the globe.
  • More common in pediatric patients undergoing squint surgery.
  • The reflex arc involves the afferents passing from the orbital contents to ciliary ganglion to the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve to the sensory nucleus of the trigeminal near the fourth ventricle. The efferent passes via the vagus which is parasympathetic to the heart.
  • The reflex results in bradycardia, atrioventricular block, ventricular ectopy or sometimes asystole.
  • This can be prevented by pre-treatment with atropine or glycopyrrolate.

questions.text: Muscle relaxant to be avoided in a hypertensive patient?
questions.solution:
• Pancuronium is avoided in hypertensive patients because it causes vagal blockade and sympathetic stimulation.
  • Sympathetic stimulation is due to ganglionic stimulation, neural release of catecholamines and inhibition of reuptake of catecholamines. Hence It can aggravate hypertension.
  • But when it is used in small increments slowly, it doesn’t produce significant changes in heart rate and blood pressure.
  • For the same reason, it is to be cautiously used in patients with coronary artery disease, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and aortic stenosis.

questions.text: Antihypertensive agents that is to be discontinued 24-48hrs prior to surgery
questions.solution:
• Antihypertensive agents that is to be discontinued 24-48hrs prior to surgery is ACE inhibitor.
  • There is a risk that hemodynamic instability and hypotension will occur during anesthesia in patients receiving ACE inhibitors.
  • Three systems exist to maintain normal blood pressure:
    • Autonomic system
    • RAAS system
    • Vasopressin system
  • Following blunting of autonomic responses by induction of anesthesia and blunting of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system by an ACE inhibitor, the only remaining system to support blood pressure is the vasopressin system, and so blood pressure is likely to be volume dependent.
  • ACE inhibitors may also decrease cardiac output by attenuating the venoconstrictor effect of angiotensin on capacitance vessels. This will result in a decrease in venous return. Maintenance of intravascular fluid volume is crucial during surgery in patients on long-term treatment with these drugs.
  • Surgical procedures involving major fluid shifts have been associated with refractory hypotension in patients being treated with ACE inhibitors.

questions.text: Venous air embolism (VAE) is a potential complication of surgery in the sitting position. Regarding VAE, the correct statement is:

choices.text: All VAE can be detected clinically by a decrease in end tidal carbon dioxide
A decrease in oxygen saturation will not always be seen, even with larger emboli
Patients with left to right shunt, are susceptible to paradoxical air embolism
The surgeon has no role in the management of VAE

questions.solution:
The correct statement regarding VAE is decrease in oxygen saturation will not always be seen, even with larger emboli.

Physiological monitors (heart rate, blood pressure, oxygen saturation and end tidal carbon dioxide) have poor sensitivity and specificity and the clinical signs are manifested late. 

Trans esophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is the most sensitive monitor and can detect upto 0.02ml/kg of air embolism.

Patients with right to left shunt are susceptible to paradoxical emboli.

Surgeons should be notified immediately in order to apply fluid to the surgical field to prevent further embolism.

questions.text: Inhalational agent of choice for a patient posted for liver transplantation?
questions.solution:
• Liver transplantation is carried out under general anesthesia with an inhalational agent usually sevoflurane and isoflurane but sevoflurane may be the anesthetic of choice as it is considered equal to or better than isoflurane in preserving hepatic arterial blood flow and hepatic oxygen delivery.
  • There is an autoregulatory mechanism in liver called the hepatic arterial buffer response(HABF)- when portal blood flow decreases due to decreased cardiac output or hypovolemia, the hepatic arterial blood flow increases in order to maintain total hepatic blood flow. This response is best preserved with sevoflurane and isoflurane but disrupted by halothane.
  • Hepatic artery vasoconstriction is seen with halothane along with an increase in hepatic arterial resistance. There is also reduction in hepatic oxygen delivery and hepatic venous oxygen saturation. This is because of the greater reduction in cardiac output seen with halothane than the other volatile agents.
  • In patients with severe encephalopathy the concentration of sevoflurane to be used is less than one minimum alveolar concentration.

questions.text: In Damage Control resuscitation (DCR), the ratio of RBCs, fresh frozen plasma and platelets is of the order:
questions.solution:
• In DCR, the ratio of RBC: FFP: Platelets is 1:1:1.
  • Administering blood products in the appropriate ratios in order to facilitate resuscitation from trauma and avert trauma induced coagulopathy is termed Damage Control Resuscitation (DCR).
  • Red blood cell component will improve oxygen delivery to ischemic tissues.
  • Fresh frozen plasma improves clotting by providing clotting factors V and VIII and fibrinogen.
  • Platelet transfusion is required if the platelet count is below 50,000 / high power field, significant blood loss or prolonged resuscitation.
  • Though the current hemostatic resuscitation ratio is 1:1:1, use of less fresh frozen plasma and more of antifibrinolytics is advocated by some experts.

questions.text: While performing this block the patient experienced sudden pain in the eye, proptosis, diminished vision, and a sudden increase in intraocular pressure. What procedure-related complication would you suspect?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the technique of retrobulbar block and the complication that can be suspected in this patient is retrobulbar hemorrhage.

A retrobulbar block is a regional anesthesia technique used in ophthalmic surgery which involves the injection of a local anesthetic into the extraocular muscle cone. The needle penetrates the lower lid at the junction of the outer and middle third of the orbit. After aspiration to rule out intravascular injection, 2 to 5 mL of local anesthetic (lidocaine 2% or bupivacaine 0.75%) is injected, and the needle is removed.

Complications of retrobulbar block include:

  • Retrobulbar hemorrhage (most common complication) - Venous hemorrhage spreads slowly but arterial hemorrhage can produce a rapid swelling. This may compress surrounding vital structures and present with marked proptosis, immobility of the globe, inability to close the lids, and blood staining of the conjunctiva and the lids. Compression on the retinal vasculature can cause severe vision loss. 
  • Postretrobulbar block apnea syndrome: This may occur if the anesthetic is injected into the optic nerve sheath.
  • Perforation of the globe
  • Oculocardiac reflex
  • Accidental intravascular injection of the local anesthetic
  • Respiratory arrest

Contraindications of retrobulbar block:

  • Bleeding disorders - This is because of the risk of retrobulbar hemorrhage 
  • High myopia - Increased length of the globe increases the risk of perforation
  • Open eye injury (penetrating eye injury) - injection of local anesthetic behind the globe could increase the intraocular pressure which could lead to extrusion of the orbital contents.

Other options:

Option A: Retinal detachment: Can present with non-specific symptoms initially, but later present with photopsia (transient flashes of light), floaters (small moving spots in the retinal field), or a gradually developing veil/ curtain obscuring field of vision.

Option B: Subconjunctival haemorrhage: It is usually asymptomatic, but a momentary sharp pain or a snapping sensation can be felt. It is seen on elderly individuals and occurs either spontaneously or follows trauma, surgery or conjunctivitis.

Option C: Optic neuritis: It is characterised by loss of vision, deteriorating in hours to days, along with local tenderness. Often the vision improves spontaneously.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for brain death, except:
questions.solution:
All the options are criteria for brain death, except absent deep tendon reflexes. Deep tendon reflexes/ spinal cord reflexes may be present in brain death as the spinal cord function below C1 is intact. 

Clinical criteria for brain death:

  • Coma- Deep, unresponsiveness to noxious stimuli
  • Absent motor activity- No decerebrate or decorticate posturing
  • Absence of brainstem reflexes- Pupillary, oculocephalic, corneal, gag reflex, etc.
  • Apnea- Absence of spontaneous respiration at  arterial pCO2 tension of at least 50–60 mmHg

Confirmatory test findings (not mandatory but may assist in diagnosis)

  • Isoelectric electroencephalogram
  • Absence of somatosensory evoked potentials and brainstem evoked potentials 
  • Absence of cerebral perfusion, as documented by angiographic, transcranial Doppler, or radioisotopic studies

questions.text: The following are indications of mechanical ventilation except?
questions.solution:
Arterial CO2 tension < 50 mm Hg is not a indication for mechanical indication.

Indications of mechanical ventilation

Direct measurement:

  • Arterial oxygen tension <50 mm Hg on room air
  • Arterial CO2 tension >50 mm Hg in the absence of metabolic alkalosis

Derived indices:

  • Pa O2 /F IO2 ratio <300 mm Hg
  • PA–a o2 gradient >350 mm Hg
  • V D /V T >0.6

Clinical indices:

  • Respiratory rate >35 breaths/min

Mechanical indices:

  • Tidal volume <5 mL/kg
  • Vital capacity <15 mL/kg
  • Maximum inspiratory Force > −25 cm H2O

questions.text: During surgery after inhalational anesthesia a patient suddenly developed fever, increased heart rate and BP, acidosis and arrhythmia. What will be your line of management?
questions.solution:
Sudden development of fever, tachycardia, hypertension, arrhythmia and acidosis after inhalational anesthesia (most probably halogenated drug) or succinyl choline suggest an episode of malignant hyperthermia. Treatment include immediately stopping the triggering agent and administering dantrolene.

Malignant Hyperthermia key features:

  • Features - Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, cyanosis, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypertension
  • Protective drugs - Thiopentone & pancuronium.
  • Safe anesthetics - N2O, Nondepolarizing muscle relaxants, opiates, tranquilizers, etomidate, barbiturates (thiopentone), benzodiazepines, propofol, ketamine and regional anesthesia.
  • Drugs causing malignant hyperthermia are – succinyl choline, halothane, iso / des / sevo / methoxyl flurane, TCA MAO inhibitors & phenothiazines.
  • Pediatric age & muscle dystrophy predispose to MH.
  • Hyperthermia, hyperkalemia, hypernatremia, hyperphosphatemia and myoglobinuria Indicate muscle damage.
  • Treatment: Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents, hyperventilation with 100% O2, dantrolene, NaHCO3 and cooling measures are used in treatment.
  • Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia but it is to be reconstituted with sterile distilled water not saline as it can precipitate in saline or other salt solutions. It is given at a dose of 2.5 mg/ kg intravenously and can be repeated every 5-10 minutes till the attack subsides.

questions.text: Propofol infusion syndrome is associated with all except:
questions.solution:
Propofol infusion syndrome is not associated with Nephropathy

Propofol infusion syndrome is a rare but lethal syndrome seen when the dose of propofol infusion is greater than 4 mg/kg/hour for 48 hours or longer. It is common in children and critically ill adults.

  • Clinical Features:
    • Acute refractory bradycardia leading to asystole in the presence of one or more of the following:
      • Metabolic acidosis (base deficit >10 mmol/L)
      • Rhabdomyolysis
      • Hyperlipidemia
      • Enlarged or fatty liver
      • Other features include cardiomyopathy with acute cardiac failure, skeletal myopathy, hyperkalemia, hepatomegaly, and lipemia.
  • The symptoms and signs are the results of muscle injury and the release of intracellular toxic contents.
  • It is thought to be due to a defect in mitochondrial metabolism and electron transport chain function.

questions.text: TRUE statement concerning etomidate is

choices.text: Has been used to treat hypercortisolemia
To be avoided in neurosurgical procedures due to risk of raised intracranial pressure

questions.solution:
• Etomidate can be used in the treatment of endogenous hypercortisolemia. This is due to its ability to inhibit the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase, which results in decreased biosynthesis of cortisol.
  • Etomidate has the highest incidence of Postoperative nausea and vomiting.
  • Etomidate can be safely used in neurosurgical procedures such as giant aneurysm clipping. It is also the anesthetic induction agent of choice to reduce increased ICP when maintenance of cerebral or coronary perfusion pressure is important.
  • Of all induction agents, etomidate is the most cardiac stable induction agent and is the agent of choice in CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE, cardiomyopathy, cerebral vascular disease or hypovolemia.

questions.text: A patient is posted for posterior fossa decompression surgery. What is your inhalation anesthetic of choice?
questions.solution:
• Among the given options, isoflurane is best suited for neurosurgery.
  • All of the inhalational anesthetics are cerebral vasodilators. The order of vasodilating potency is halothane → enflurane→ desflurane → isoflurane → sevoflurane.
  • Though isoflurane increases cerebral blood flow and intracranial pressure these effects are  less pronounced than with halothane ,nitrous oxide and ether.
  • Though inhalational anesthetics are used in neuroanesthesia, if the intracranial pressure is persistently raised, they should be replaced with intravenous agents.
  • Earlier, it had been believed that isoflurane is cerebroprotective in the presence of ischemia, but now no such evidence of cerebral protection has been documented and there is no difference among the inhaled anesthetics in this respect.

questions.text: Which of the following statement about halothane is incorrect?

choices.text: It sensitizes the heart to catecholamine at 1MAC
It is not usually given in same patient with in 3 months

questions.solution:
• Halothane contains 0.01% thymol for stability.
  • 15-20% of absorbed halothane is metabolized.
  • Halothane may persist in the liver for as long as 12days after administration and is usually not given in same patient within 3 months.
  • It sensitizes heart to arrythmogenic action of epinephrine, so doses of 1.5microgram/kg should be avoided.

questions.text: Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) is increased by?
questions.solution:
LAST is increased by:

  • Hypercapnia
  • Hypoxia
  • Acidosis (metabolic and respiratory)
  • Decreased plasma protein binding of LA (due to increased PaCO2 or decreased pH)
  • Abnormally low protein concentration (in neonates increasing the proportion of free drug)
  • Advanced age
  • Hepatic failure leading to decreased clearance of amide LA
  • Renal failure
  • Cardiac failure (prolonged absorption and drug accumulation)
  • Underlying cardiac pathology (IHD, CCF, conduction block)

High yield points in local anaesthetics:

Cocaine:Naturally occurring

Vasoconstrictor

1st Local anesthetic 

Chlorprocaine:

Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia 

Prilocaine:

Safest

Causes maximum methemoglobinemia

Most suitable for bier’s IV block

EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine 

Bupivacaine:

Most potent and best for isobaric spinal anaesthesia

Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia

Most cardiotoxic

Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretyllium (for VT), vasopressors e.g. epinephrine, vasopressin (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative) Long acting 

Procaine:

LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia

1st synthetic LA

Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions 

Mepivacaine:

Not metabolized by neonates so contraindicated in neonates and labor 

Lignocaine:

It can be useful in acute intravenous therapy of ventricular arrhythmias.

Not useful in atrial arrhythmias

Least cardiotoxic antiarrhythmic

Toxicity includes CNS-vertigo, convulsion, respiratory failure; hypotension , cardiac failure, depress hypoxic drive, apnea, bronchospasm. – LAST (Local Anesthesia Systemic Toxicity)

questions.text: False statement about nausea and vomiting associated with neuraxial blockade is

choices.text: Hyopotension following spinal anesthesia is a cause
Adding epinephrine to local anesthetic predisposes
Atropine may be effective in treatment
Among intrathecal opioids, morphine has the least incidence of nausea and vomiting

questions.solution:
Among the opioids commonly added to intrathecal or epidural local anesthetics, morphine administration has the most risk of nausea and vomiting whereas fentanyl  and sufentanil carry the least frequent risk.

Possible mechanisms that contribute to nausea and vomiting in the setting of neuraxial anesthesia: 

  • Direct exposure of the chemoreceptive trigger zone in the brain to emetogenic drugs (e.g., opioids)
  • Hypotension associated with generalized vasodilation
  • Gastrointestinal hyperperistalsis secondary to unopposed parasympathetic activity

Factors associated with developing nausea or vomiting after spinal anesthesia include:

  • Addition of phenylephrine or epinephrine to local anesthetics
  • Peak block height greater than or equal to T5
  • Baseline heart rate greater than 60 beats/min
  • Use of procaine
  • History of motion sickness

Atropine is effective in treating nausea associated with high (T5) subarachnoid anesthesia.

questions.text: A child was in the postoperative ward following a tonsillectomy. Pain needs to be assessed and the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Pain Scale (CHEOPS) for rating postoperative pain was used. It includes all of the following, except _____.
questions.solution:
The Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Pain Scale (CHEOPS) includes all the options, except oxygen saturation.

CHEOPS is a behavioral scale used to measure postoperative pain in young children. It helps in assessing the effectiveness of interventions to reduce pain and discomfort.

It measures crying, facial expression, body position (torso), verbal expression, touch position, and leg position.

Other pain assessment scales in children include:

  • Oucher face scale
  • Visual analog scale (VAS)

questions.text: Order of susceptibility of nerve fibers to local anesthetics is as follows
questions.solution:
Order of susceptibility of nerve fibers to local anesthetics: B > A gamma> A delta> A alpha=Abeta>C.

Note: This is a controversial topic.

According to Miller's Anesthesia 8th ed page no 1688, B > A gamma> A delta> A alpha=Abeta>C 

According to Katzung Pharmacology 14th ed page no 465,  B=C> A delta> A gamma> A beta> A alpha

According to Ganong's Physiology 23rd ed page no 90, C >B>A

There is an obvious discrepancy between the different standard textbooks and the correct answer solely depends on the reference used to set the question in the exam.

questions.text: A poorly controlled diabetic with retinopathy would be placed under?
questions.solution:
ASA GRADE 3: Patient with severe systemic disease (some functional limitations)

  • Poorly controlled diabetes: Severe systemic disease
  • Retinopathy: Functional limitation due to poor vision or loss of vision

- American Society of Anesthesiologists’(ASA) classification is used to define relative risk prior to conscious sedation and surgical anesthesia.

- It is simple, reproducible and strongly correlates to perioperative risk

American Society of Anesthesiologists’ physical status classification of patients -  Class Definition

  • 1 Normal healthy patient
  • 2 Patient with mild systemic disease (no functional limitations)
  • 3 Patient with severe systemic disease (some functional limitations)
  • 4 Patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life (functionality incapacitated)
  • 5 A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation
  • 6 A brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

 

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text: A patient on tablet FLUOXETINE for depression for the past 2 months is posted for elective surgery. Advice regarding use of fluoxetine?

choices.text: Withhold  Fluoxetine for 3 weeks prior to  surgery
Withhold fluoxetine  for 3 days prior to surgery
Withhold fluoxetine and replace with MonoAmine Oxidase inhibitors

questions.solution:
• Fluoxetine is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor SSRI, an antidepressant, which is to be continued on the day of surgery to avoid exacerbation of symptoms
  • Abrupt discontinuation of SSRIs can lead to dizziness, headache,nausea, irritability, visual disturbances, and sensation of electric shock
  • All antidepressants, antipsychotics, and anxiolytics are to be continued on the day of surgery
  • Earlier irreversible monoamine oxidase inhibitor MAOI antidepressants were discontinued 3 weeks preoperatively and reversible MAOI was discontinued 24 hrs prior to surgery. But discontinuing these drugs resulted in episodes of severe depression or even suicides. Thus it is now recommended to continue these drugs and adjust the anesthetic plan so as to avoid the use of meperidine and indirect-acting vasopressors.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman was taken up for Cesarean section. Spinal anesthesia was given and the patient went into hypotension. Which of the following would be the vasopressor of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Phenylephrine is the vasopressor of choice in pregnant patients developing hypotension following neuraxial anesthesia (spinal and epidural).

Phenylephrine is preferred because besides effectively controlling hypotension, it has less placental transfer and lesser chances of fetal acidosis than ephedrine.

The patient should receive an adequate intravenous fluid bolus of crystalloid like Ringer lactate solution (typically 1000–1500 mL) or colloid (typically 250–500 mL) solution at the time of neural blockade to avoid hypotension. On developing hypotension even after adequate fluid management, vasopressors are administered for the further management.

After the administration of the spinal anesthetic injection, the patient is placed supine with left uterine displacement (to prevent aortocaval compression) and supplemental oxygen (40–50%) is given.

Blood pressure should be monitored every 1–2 min until it stabilizes.

Hypotension following epidural anesthesia typically has a slower onset.

Other options:

Option A- Dopamine is not used in pregnant women developing hypotension because it lowers the pO2 levels in umbilical vessels. 

Option B- Vasopressin is reserved for circulatory collapse or patients who do not respond to volume infusion and catecholamines. Hence, it is not preferred here.

Option C- Ephedrine has more placental transfer and there is a higher risk of fetal acidosis.

questions.text: The Local anesthetic of choice for labor analgesia is?
questions.solution:
Bupivacaine and ropivacaine are preferred over lidocaine and chloroprocaine for labor analgesia because of their differential blockade  (they produce less motor blockade as compared to sensory blockade). This preferred motor function is useful as voluntary push down efforts by the patient may lead to better delivery outcomes

Bupivacaine is preferred because of its long duration of action

Ropivacaine and levobupivacaine were introduced to reduce the cardiotoxicity associated with bupivacaine. But since bupivacaine is used in small doses for labor analgesia, cardiotoxicity usually does not manifest

The doses of local anesthetics can be reduced by a combination of local anesthetics with lipid-soluble opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil. The greater the concentration of opioid used, a lesser concentration of local anesthetic is required. The lesser concentration of local anesthetic used leads to greater preservation of motor function and makes ambulation of the  patient possible(walking or mobile epidural)

Concentrations used for epidural:

  • Without opioid: bupivacaine: 0.25%, ropivacaine, 0.2%
  • With opioid: bupivacaine (0.0625% to 0.125%), ropivacaine (0.0625% to 0.2%)

questions.text: The induction agent of choice in a child with croup is:
questions.solution:
The induction agent of choice in a child with croup is sevoflurane.

Viral croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) is responsible for the majority of cases of acute stridor in children. It occurs due to infection with parainfluenza viruses commonly, but it may also be caused by influenza viruses type A or B, respiratory syncytial virus, or rhinovirus. Children aged 6 months to 3 years are commonly affected. Infection results in subglottic and tracheal swelling causing stridor and other signs of respiratory obstruction.

In infants and young children, the upper and lower airways are small, prone to occlusion by secretions, and susceptible to edema and swelling. As a result, the resistance to laminar airflow increases in inverse proportion to the fourth power of the radius (Poiseuille's law). Therefore, a small decrease in the radius of the airway results in a marked increase in resistance to airflow and the work of breathing. Children are more reliant on the diaphragm for inspiration, due to the relative immaturity of the intercostal muscles and accessory muscles.

Treatment includes humidification of respiratory gases, oxygen, steroids, and nebulized epinephrine. Steroids reduce symptoms and improve croup scores 6–24 h after initial dosing, thereby reducing the need for intubation or shortening the time to extubation.

Severe respiratory obstruction, as indicated by a persistently high croup score of >7, despite ongoing medical treatment, is an indication for tracheal intubation. Oxygen should be given by mask if required. Historically, halothane was the agent of choice for induction and maintenance of anesthesia in upper airway obstruction however, sevoflurane is safe and effective in this situation. 

Halothane has largely been replaced by sevoflurane, particularly for induction. Studies show that the incidence of complications in children with mild upper respiratory tract infection was similar between sevoflurane and halothane but that sevoflurane provided a more rapid recovery profile. Other studies, however, suggest that sevoflurane results in fewer complications than halothane, particularly when sevoflurane is used for both induction and maintenance. 

Other options:

Option A - Nitrous oxide is odorless. It is also commonly used for inhalational induction in cooperative children but is not the agent of choice for induction in children with croup.

Option C - Isoflurane has a relatively more noxious smell than sevoflurane, which makes an inhalational induction with it unacceptable for most children.

Option D - Desflurane is not suitable for inhalational induction in children because of its pungent odor and the associated effects of laryngospasm. 

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

Isoflurane 1.2 1.4

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

questions.text: Identify the most common complication of a celiac plexus block.
questions.solution:
The most common complication of a celiac plexus block is postural hypotension.

This occurs due to the resultant blockade of the lumbar sympathetic chain and the dilation of capacitance vessels in the splanchnic area. Therefore, patients should be adequately hydrated intravenously prior to this procedure and precautions should be taken to minimize the risk of orthostatic lightheadedness or syncope.

The celiac ganglia are found at the level of the body of the L1 vertebra. They are located lateral to the aorta, and posterior to the vena cava and the pancreas.

It is preferred when patients have pain originating from the abdominal viscera, as seen in intra-abdominal cancers.

Due to its proximity to the vena cava, accidental intravascular injection into the vena cava can occur, which can produce a severe systemic reaction. Damage to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes can result in chylothorax. Blocking the sympathetic chain leads to increased gastrointestinal motility due to unopposed parasympathetic activity, resulting in diarrhea.

It may lead to other complications such as pneumothorax, injury to the kidneys or pancreas, hemorrhage, sexual dysfunction, paraplegia due to injury to the lumbar artery of Adamkiewicz, and back pain.

questions.text: What is the range of value of Bispectral index (BIS) for a patient who is under general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
The Bispectral index value range of 40-60 is seen in a patient under general anesthesia. 

The bispectral index (BIS) is an empirically derived scale that helps to monitor the depth of anesthesia and prevent intraoperative awareness. It processes the EEG and provides an index value between 0 to 100 that indicates the patient’s level of consciousness.

Bispectral index value range: 

  • 100 - Awake and response to normal voice present
  • 80 - Light/moderate sedation (May respond to loud commands or mild prodding/shaking)
  • 60 - General anesthesia (Low probability of explicit recall, Unresponsive to verbal stimulus)
  • 40 - Deep hypnotic state
  • 20 - Burst suppression
  • 0 - Flatline EEG

questions.text: The following capnographic waveform is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given capnographic waveform is suggestive of bronchospasm.

Capnography refers to the method of CO2 measurement as a function of time or volume. Bronchospasms may be due to respiratory pathologies like asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), or acute lung injury. Another cause of this waveform is a partially obstructed endotracheal tube or breathing circuit. Capnographic changes in bronchospasm include:

  • Loss of verticality of Phase II
  • The opening of the angle between phases 2 and 3 (α angle)
  • Increased upslope of phase III
  • No plateau before the next inspiration
  • Shark fin appearance - in severe cases

 Normal capnography is shown in the image below:

Other options:

Option A: Malignant hyperthermia would show a progressive rise in the end-tidal CO2 due to the increased metabolic rate.

Option C: Rebreathing will show the failure of CO2 to return to the baseline at the end of the expiration. The inspiratory CO2 remains above 0.

Option D: Accidental extubation or circuit disconnection would show a sudden cessation of CO2.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.
